rows.text: A mid-August meeting was well and fashionably attended on a meadow near Gogerddan about three miles from the town.
Early records show that racing took place at Abingdon as early as 1767.The flat, oval racecourse had a circumference of 10 furlongs and a separate 6 furlong section for sprint races.
Held a one-day meeting in September, with a £50 town plate being the principal race
Run at a course one mile south-west of the town, on the site of what is supposed to have been a Danish camp. Formerly at Beadnell.
Held a day-long meeting at the end of September, including a Town Plate of £50
Held a 'poorly-attended' two-day meeting in early October
Near Ludlow, it held a day's 'inferior' racing in mid-July
Held a meeting towards the end of August which included the 100 sovereign Dorsetshire Gold Cup
Held one day's racing in September
A course near the town, with a 'commodious' stand held races for two days in late September
Held two days' racing at the end of September
Held a two-day meeting at the start of August; the course was in bad repair in 1840
Held a day long race meeting in mid-August
Held two days' racing in the middle of August, including a Gold Cup of 100 sovs
Held one day's racing in mid-October. Held the 'Ordinaries' at The Star Inn, Burntwood.
Held a two-day meeting at the end of August which included the Bretby Cup, given by the Earl of Chesterfield
Held two days' racing in June
Held on Barham Downs, within 3 miles of the city. Had a 'commodious stand'. Was awarded a King's Plate by George II in 1729.{{sfn|Whyte|1840|p=402}}
Held mid-July meetings for two days.
Held one day's 'inferior racing' at the beginning of September
Held two days' racing at the start of October
Held two days' racing at the beginning of May
The first record of racing was 1617 http://www.greyhoundderby.com/Clitheroe%20Racecourse.html the link has a map too.
Two-day race meetings were held in March with a Silver Cup and £100 in prize money
Held amateur races at the beginning of April
Site now occupied by Long Lane Estate and Ashburton Playing Fields.
Held two days' racing in the middle of September
Held two days racing at the end of June
Alternately held the Caledonian Hunt meeting, along with Ayr, Edinburgh and Musselburgh
Situated on the plain of Runnymede where King John signed the Magna Carta, Egham races were often attended by royalty. The course was a two mile flat oval.
A mile and a half oblong course in a meadow on the banks of the River Severn, with a straight, 400 yard run-in
Had four courses ranging in length from 5 furlongs 136 yards to two miles
Three-day meetings held in the middle of June on Moulsey Hurst next to the river
Held a two-day meeting at the end of September which included the Town Plate and St. Leonard's Plate, both of 50 sovereigns
Situated on a common near the town called Portfield or Poorfield. Two-day meetings were held at the beginning of August.
Held three days 'excellent' racing in late September

Races were held on the 'heathy downs' at Cannock Chase which had long been famed for racehorses. A day long meeting was held in early July and again in October and November. These races did not run from 1835 to 1871 consecutively. The first meeting was on Tuesday 27 October 1835 and ran for seven years until Tuesday 8 November 1842. Another meeting was held on Tuesday 26 November 1850 with the final meeting being on Monday 30 October 1871.
Races took place at the beginning of August for two days
A 'vast establishment' also called the Metropolitan Racecourse
Hunt races took place in the middle of October for two days.
Racing, mainly hunter chases, took place at the end of April and for a short time in the 1820s and 1830s the course was very fashionable
An 'inferior' racecourse, with meetings at the end of July
Held two-day race meetings in mid-June.
Held a two-day meeting in late July
Held races that were only 'of local interest' in 1840

Races were held on the sands at low tide in late July or early August for four or five days, until the events were moved to Musselburgh. A 4 mile King's Plate was run at Leith from at least 1728{{sfn|Whyte|1840|p=403}}
Held meetings at the end of August

The course was on the Tamworth road, about two miles from the city and raced at the end of March and in mid-September. Was awarded a King's Plate for 5 year olds by George II in 1748.{{sfn|Whyte|1840|page=402}}
The course was situated just over a mile east of the town, the area between the straights (which crossed both Eakring Road and Southwell Road) is still used for recreational purposes.
Races were held annually in November on Middleham Moor, but in 1840 they were deemed 'of little interest'. Middleham is still home to many racing stables.
Situated on the banks of the River Wye near the junction with the River Monnow on Chippenham meadow. A two-day meeting was held in mid-October.
Races took place over two days at the beginning of September at Cottingwood to the north of the town.
Held a two-day meeting in early August
Held a two-day meeting at the end of July
Racing took place in mid-October for two days, and included a £100 Gold Cup and £50 Silver Cup.

Racing started on the common west of the town over a unique figure-of-eight course. A grandstand was built at the start of the 19th century. but the last meeting was held in 1848. Its regular meeting was two days in September and included the Shropshire Stakes and a Gold Cup.
An oval of two miles, quite flat
Situated between the River Avon and the canal to Newport, Wales. A two-day meeting was held at the start of August.
Held a two-day meeting at the start of August including a Stewards' Plate of 100 sovs.

Racing took place for two days in mid-September on Whitcliffe Meadow, an area of common ground, which was "an excellent course". The link below provides a wonderfully detailed description of the course and plans to transform it into a conservation area:-https://www.richmondshire.gov.uk/media/4936/richmond-racecourse-conservation-area-study.pdf
Held a two-day meeting at the beginning of September
Held a one day meeting in the middle of May, for 'half-bred horses' of local interest only
Held two days of 'inferior racing' at the end of May

Situated on Bicton Heath, 2 miles west of Shrewsbury. It was 1 mile 185 yards round. Races took place in mid-September for 3 or 4 days and included a Queen's Plate of 100gs. In Chris Pitt's book, A Long TIme Gone, he states the meetings began in 1774 but there is evidence on John Slusar's website, The Greyhound Derby, that shows it was 1730.
Situated on Southampton common on land given by the corporation. Held a two-day meeting at the beginning of August.
A one mile course, almost completely oval except for a quarter mile straight run-in. Held 'very inferior' races at the start of October.
A mile in circumference on Wittoring Heath near the town, held a three day mid-June meeting.
A meeting of merely local interest was held at the end of April
Held a two-day meeting in early October.
Held two days of racing at the end of August. Had a Cup Stakes of £100 in value.
Held at a place called Noman's Land. Home to the St. Albans' Steeple Chase. Racing ceased on the establishment of Gorhambury Park.
Commonly called 'Swansea and Neath races', the course was on Cremlyn Burrows on the Neath Road. Meetings were held at the end of August.
An oval, hilly, two mile course with a one day meeting at the beginning of May
Racing of a 'very inferior' nature, with the principal race being a £50 plate.
Held a two-day meeting at the end of August
Held a well attended two-day meeting at the end of August on the common
Races took place at the end of August
The majority of race meetings were held over two days at the end of September although some years the meeting was held in October and towards the end, in August.
Held a 'very inferior' race meeting at the beginning of October
Held one day's racing at the end of July
Well attended meeting held at the end of August. The course was considered 'very good'
Circa 1914 requisitioned during WW I and remains in military ownership
Races were held on Worthy Down, 4 miles from Winchester for two days in the middle of July. Held a Royal Plate race for 6 year olds from at least 1727.{{sfn|Whyte|1840|p=402}}
